Sir, On 7th June, 1949, you forwarded to this Department a copy of a letter dated 21st May, from His Majesty’s representative in Bahrain in which it was stated that no regulations existed regarding the importation of livestock from Great Britain into Bahrain or the other Sheikhdoms of the Persian Gulf. An exporter recently informed the Ministry that, as a condition of entry to Bahrain, a dog was required to be injected against rabies. It would therefore appear that some regulation are now in force and it would be appreciated if enquiries could be made in this connection. It is suggested that the appropriate authorities might also be informed that as Great Britain is free from rabies no anti-rabic vaccine is allowed into this country and the injection of a dog with this vaccine when coming from Great Britain is therefore out of the question. As an alternative safeguard, however, this Department is prepared to provide a certificate stating that the country is free from rabies, and perhaps injection of the animals concerned could be done on their arrival in Bahrain. I am, Sir, Your obedient Servant, (Signed) D.P. Reed. The Under-Secretary of State, Foreign Office, S.W.l.I political Agency, No.2911-2/17 Bahrain, 20th Sept.1950. mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence and telegrams regarding the import of dogs and livestock into Bahrain, restrictions and compulsory anti rabies vaccinations.The main correspondents are the Adviser to the Government of Bahrain, the Director of Customs and Port Officer in Bahrain, British Overseas Airways Corporation, the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, and the Political Agent at Bahrain. There are also requests for dogs to transit into Bahrain.
